title: 105_hr2184
content:
The Act titled "Private Security Officer Quality Assurance Act of 1997" is cited as the short title. Private security officers in the United States are growing rapidly and function as an adjunct to public law enforcement. The industry provides opportunities for entry-level job applicants and protects individuals and various properties such as banks, hospitals, and airports. Private security officers in the United States protect diverse operations like banks, hospitals, airports, and residential properties. Sworn law enforcement officers serve the public, with private security officers supplementing their services. The growth of private shopping malls means more public interaction with private security personnel. Private security personnel provide prevention and reporting services alongside sworn police officers. The increase in private shopping malls has led to more public interaction with private security personnel than with law enforcement officers. The growth of security services has accelerated as the number of public sector law enforcement officers has decreased, serving public policy goals in combating serious crimes. Despite differences in duties, the public struggles to differentiate between private security and law enforcement officers. The public demands well-trained private security personnel to complement, not replace, law enforcement officers. Private security officers should undergo thorough screening, especially those carrying weapons. SEC. 3. BACKGROUND CHECKS. Background checks for private security officers can be requested by employers through an association designated by the Attorney General. The association must submit fingerprints for background checks, which will be searched through national crime databases and provided within 30 days. Employees can authorize the submission of their fingerprints for these checks. The Attorney General conducts background checks for private security officers through national crime databases, providing identification and criminal history records within 30 days. Associations must submit employee fingerprints promptly for processing. An association designated under this section must promptly submit employee fingerprints to the Attorney General for processing and provide identification and criminal history records to the requesting employer within one business day. Additionally, the association must share this information with licensing authorities and regulatory agencies in the relevant states. The Attorney General has the authority to establish regulations for the implementation of this section, including measures related to security, confidentiality, accuracy, and use. The Attorney General may prescribe regulations for the security, confidentiality, accuracy, and dissemination of information related to the transfer of employee fingerprints and criminal history records by designated associations to employers and states. Additionally, the Attorney General will report to Congress on the number of inquiries made by employers under this section after two years of the bill's enactment. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS.

Subsection (d) of section 534 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include an association of employers of private security officers designated by the Attorney General for conducting background checks on employees.

SEC. 5. CRIMINAL PENALTY.

Anyone who misuses information obtained under section 3 for purposes other than assessing an individual's suitability for private security officer employment may face a fine of up to $50,000 or imprisonment for up to two years, or both.

SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY. SEC. 5. CRIMINAL PENALTY.

Using information from section 3 for purposes other than private security officer employment may result in a fine of up to $50,000 or imprisonment for up to two years, or both. In this Act, key terms are defined such as "Attorney General," "employee," "employer," "fingerprint," and "private security officer." The definition of an employer includes providing services of private security officers and being licensed or certified by states. The term "private security officer" refers to an individual who provides security services for compensation, whether armed or unarmed, in uniform or plain clothes. It does not include sworn police officers with law enforcement powers, attorneys, or accountants. The term "fingerprint" includes any approved method of positive identification. Private security officers are individuals who provide security services for compensation, whether armed or unarmed, in uniform or plain clothes. This does not include sworn police officers with law enforcement powers, attorneys, accountants, or individuals on active duty in the military service. Private security officers are individuals who provide security services for compensation, including those whose duties involve reporting or apprehending shoplifters, individuals on active duty in the military, employees of electronic security system companies, employees involved in the secure movement of prisoners, and employees of armored vehicle companies. Security services encompass observing or reporting intrusion, larceny, vandalism, fire, or trespass. The term "security services" includes observing and reporting intrusion, theft, unlawful activity, protecting individuals and property, controlling access, maintaining order at public events. The term "security services" encompass protecting individuals and property, controlling access, maintaining order at public events, and providing canine services for detecting unlawful devices or substances. The term "State" refers to various regions including States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories. The Attorney General may collect user fees for requests for criminal history information. The effective date of this Act is July 1, 1999.
